node.title: libmesh build error on INL cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am a LANL-postdoc developing surrogate models in MOOSE (working with Laurent Capolungo, Topher Matthews and Andrea Rovinelli). I am relatively new to working with MOOSE on the INL cluster and experiencing problems installing libmesh on the INL cluster (sawtooth) through update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh. I have just cloned MOOSE, compiled PETSC successfully (update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh), and get an error during libmesh build (see first few lines of error copied below). How can I resolve this to compile libmesh?
Warm regards,
Andre Ruybalid
../src/base/libmesh.C: In constructor 'libMesh::LibMeshInit::LibMeshInit(int, const char* const*, TIMPI::communicator, int)':
../src/base/libmesh.C:441:38: error: 'using_threads' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'n_threads'?
441 |     new TIMPI::TIMPIInit(argc, argv, using_threads,
|                                      ^~~~~~~~~~~~~
|                                      n_threads
../src/base/libmesh.C:442:26: error: 'handle_mpi_errors' was not declared in this scope
442 |                          handle_mpi_errors);
|                          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Hello
Which modules did you load for compilers? Especially for MPI
For next time, there's a pre-built PETSC module you can load on hpc, saves one step.
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume, thanks for your quick response. I have loaded the following:
Currently Loaded Modules:

gcc/9.3.0-gcc-4.8.5-twls   3) python/3.7-anaconda-2019.10
openmpi/4.0.5_ucx1.9       4) cmake/3.18.4-gcc-9.3.0-qhpg

Also thanks for the tip about the petsc module.
Andre

what does echo $CC $CXX return ?
You may need to set CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx when running this script

echo $CC $CXX returns:
/apps/local/spack/software/gcc-4.8.5/gcc-9.3.0-twlsdabweaw75pj2f2hq7k7vo3vilvmi/bin/gcc
/apps/local/spack/software/gcc-4.8.5/gcc-9.3.0-twlsdabweaw75pj2f2hq7k7vo3vilvmi/bin/g++
It should be the following (I had added it to .bashrc, but now am unsure if I sourced it)?
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx

Actually, I added this (in this order) to .bashrc:
module purge
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx
export F90=mpif90
export F77=mpif77
export FC=mpif90
export PETSC_DIR=/home/ruybandr/projects/moose/petsc
export PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose all
module load openmpi
module load python
module load cmake
It seems loading openmpi after export CC=mpicc and export CXX=mpicxx changes the CC and CXX selection. I am now attempting to rebuild libmesh with CC=mpicc and CXX=mpicxx.
I'll keep you posted..

ok hope it works!
mvapich2/2.3.3-gcc-9.2.0 is the one everyone uses on sawtooth I think btw. Openmpi should work too
With the pre-built petsc module, you ll have to make sure to load the relevant compiler too

It worked. So first:
module load openmpi
and subsequently set
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx
etc.
Thanks for your help.
Andre

node.title: NSFVMomentumAdvection object mass is not completely bounded by INSFVBCs
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I want to use external mesh in .msh format for FV NS kernels. However, I am getting the following error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mass", of type "INSFVMassAdvection".

The INSFVMomentumAdvection object mass is not completely bounded by INSFVBCs. Please examine sideset 0 and your FVBCs blocks.

I examined the mesh in gmsh and peacock. There is no such sideset 0. Clearly something wrong with the mesh, but I am not sure how to fix it.
[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = tamu.msh
  #dim = 3
[]

[Problem]
  fv_bcs_integrity_check = true
[]

[Variables]
  [u]
    type = INSFVVelocityVariable
    initial_condition = 0
  []
  [v]
    type = INSFVVelocityVariable
    initial_condition = 0
  []
  [w]
    type = INSFVVelocityVariable
    initial_condition = 0
  []
  [pressure]
    type = INSFVPressureVariable
  []
[]

[FVKernels]
  [mass]
    type = INSFVMassAdvection
    variable = pressure
    advected_interp_method = 'average'
    velocity_interp_method = 'rc'
    vel = 'velocity'
    pressure = pressure
    u = u
    v = v
    w = w
    mu = 1.e-3
    rho = 1.e3
  []

  [u_advection]
    type = INSFVMomentumAdvection
    variable = u
    advected_quantity = 'rhou'
    vel = 'velocity'
    advected_interp_method = 'average'
    velocity_interp_method = 'rc'
    pressure = pressure
    u = u
    v = v
    w = w
    mu = 1.e-3
    rho = 1.e3
  []
  [u_viscosity]
    type = FVDiffusion
    variable = u
    coeff =1.e-3
  []
  [u_pressure]
    type = INSFVMomentumPressure
    variable = u
    momentum_component = 'x'
    pressure = pressure
  []

  [v_advection]
    type = INSFVMomentumAdvection
    variable = v
    advected_quantity = 'rhov'
    vel = 'velocity'
    advected_interp_method = 'average'
    velocity_interp_method = 'rc'
    pressure = pressure
    u = u
    v = v
    w = w
    mu = 1.e-3
    rho = 1.e3
  []
  [v_viscosity]
    type = FVDiffusion
    variable = v
    coeff = 1.e-3
  []
  [v_pressure]
    type = INSFVMomentumPressure
    variable = v
    momentum_component = 'y'
    pressure = pressure
  []

  [w_advection]
    type = INSFVMomentumAdvection
    variable = w
    advected_quantity = 'rhow'
    vel = 'velocity'
    advected_interp_method = 'average'
    velocity_interp_method = 'rc'
    pressure = pressure
    u = u
    v = v
    w = w
    mu = 1.e-3
    rho = 1.e3
  []
  [w_viscosity]
    type = FVDiffusion
    variable = w
    coeff = 1.e-3
  []
  [w_pressure]
    type = INSFVMomentumPressure
    variable = w
    momentum_component = 'z'
    pressure = pressure
  []
[]

[FVBCs]
  [inlet-u]
    type = INSFVInletVelocityBC
    boundary = 'inlet'
    variable = u
    function = '1'
  []
  [inlet-v]
    type = INSFVInletVelocityBC
    boundary = 'inlet'
    variable = v
    function = 0
  []
  [inlet-w]
    type = INSFVInletVelocityBC
    boundary = 'inlet'
    variable = w
    function = 0
  []

  [walls-u]
    type = INSFVNoSlipWallBC
    boundary = 'wall'
    variable = u
    function = 0
  []
  [walls-v]
    type = INSFVNoSlipWallBC
    boundary = 'wall'
    variable = v
    function = 0
  []
  [walls-w]
    type = INSFVNoSlipWallBC
    boundary = 'wall'
    variable = w
    function = 0
  []

  [outlet_p]
    type = INSFVOutletPressureBC
    boundary = 'outlet'
    variable = pressure
    function = 0
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [ins_fv]
    type = INSFVMaterial
    u = 'u'
    v = 'v'
    w = 'w'
    pressure = 'pressure'
    rho = 1.e3
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      200                lu           NONZERO'
  line_search = 'none'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-12
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

Hello
sideset 0 may just be an assigned number for a side that is not part of a defined sideset, yet is on the boundary of the fluid flow domain.
You should check that ‘inlet, wall and outlet’ completely bound the flow domain, with no holes.
Can you share that mesh?
guillaume
I just looked and it seems water-tight to me. I'll dig in moose to see what's going on and I ll let you know
I understand, this is a mess. The funny thing is that mesh works with another MOOSE application (SAM, which is a finite element solver).

I got the solver to output where it's complaining about and it's in the center tube, inside the half sphere at 0.00946637, 0.179159, -0.000745019
I zoomed in on the mesh and there are some real fine elements there
Is the mesh confomal there? The solver thinks those faces are on an external boundary
The FE solver might not complain, but the results could be wrong if there's issues with the mesh
Thanks, I will try to investigate this and report later.

node.title: Output mesh element volume in FV kernels
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I am using Navier-Stokes FV kernels with 2D structured grids. I need information on the volume (or size) of the mesh elements. Is it possible to output this information?

Hello
You can place this information in an auxvariable using a VolumeAux
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/VolumeAux.html
If you care more about the length, there's this one too
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/ElementLengthAux.html
Guillaume

Thanks, that works. The only problem I face is that when I try to output this auxiliary variable with others I am getting a segmentation fault. However, I can output it using another vector postprocessor (with the same syntax).
This does not work:
[VectorPostprocessors]
  [vpp]
    type = ElementValueSampler
    variable = 'u v pressure eddy_viscosity_aux_var dudx_aux_var dudy_aux_var dvdx_aux_var dvdy_aux_var elvol_aux_var'
    sort_by = x
  []
[]

This works:
[VectorPostprocessors]
  [vpp]
    type = ElementValueSampler
    variable = 'u v pressure eddy_viscosity_aux_var dudx_aux_var dudy_aux_var dvdx_aux_var dvdy_aux_var'
    sort_by = x
  []
  [elv]
    type = ElementValueSampler
    variable = 'elvol_aux_var'
    sort_by = x
  []
[]

Is it the expected behavior?

I dont think so.
Could you please compile in debug mode and get us a backtrace on this error?

This is what I have got with debugging:
Thread 1 "fv_app-dbg" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
std::__uniq_ptr_impl<MooseVariableData, std::default_delete<MooseVariableData > >::_M_ptr (this=0x788)
at /home/aiskhak/anaconda3/envs/moose/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/include/c++/9.3.0/bits/unique_ptr.h:154
154	      pointer    _M_ptr() const { return std::get<0>(_M_t); }
Hope that helps. Let me know if (and how) I can pull more information for you.

when running it in a debugger, you should be getting a full backtrace by typing bt after it crashes. See this page for more info
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

Here is what I am getting:
#0  std::__uniq_ptr_impl<MooseVariableData<double>, std::default_delete<MooseVariableData<double> > >::_M_ptr (this=0x788)
    at /home/aiskhak/anaconda3/envs/moose/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/include/c++/9.3.0/bits/unique_ptr.h:154
#1  0x00007ffff7b3d9c7 in std::unique_ptr<MooseVariableData<double>, std::default_delete<MooseVariableData<double> > >::get (this=0x788)
    at /home/aiskhak/anaconda3/envs/moose/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/include/c++/9.3.0/bits/unique_ptr.h:361
#2  0x00007ffff7b3d97d in std::unique_ptr<MooseVariableData<double>, std::default_delete<MooseVariableData<double> > >::operator-> (this=0x788)
    at /home/aiskhak/anaconda3/envs/moose/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/include/c++/9.3.0/bits/unique_ptr.h:355
#3  0x00007ffff3d8559c in MooseVariableFE<double>::getElementalValue (this=0x0, elem=0x555555af6ce0, 
    idx=0) at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/variables/MooseVariableFE.C:196
#4  0x00007ffff40015ae in ElementValueSampler::execute (this=0x555555e4ba30)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/vectorpostprocessors/ElementValueSampler.C:66
#5  0x00007ffff4a82656 in ComputeUserObjectsThread::onElement (this=0x7fffffffcdb0, elem=0x555555af6ce0)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/loops/ComputeUserObjectsThread.C:123
#6  0x00007ffff40409cb in ThreadedElementLoopBase<libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*> >::operator() (this=0x7fffffffcdb0, range=..., bypass_threading=false)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/ThreadedElementLoopBase.h:226
#7  0x00007ffff4dd627d in libMesh::Threads::parallel_reduce<libMesh::StoredRange<libMesh::MeshBase::const_element_iterator, libMesh::Elem const*>, ComputeUserObjectsThread> (range=..., body=...)
    at /home/aiskhak/anaconda3/envs/moose/libmesh/include/libmesh/threads_pthread.h:380
#8  0x00007ffff4d95b24 in FEProblemBase::computeUserObjectsInternal(MooseEnumItem const&, Moose::AuxGroup const&, TheWarehouse::QueryCache<>&) (this=0x555555c53570, type=..., 
    group=@0x7fffffffd194: Moose::POST_AUX, query=...)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/problems/FEProblemBase.C:3932
#9  0x00007ffff4d94cda in FEProblemBase::computeUserObjects (this=0x555555c53570, type=..., 
    group=@0x7fffffffd194: Moose::POST_AUX)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/problems/FEProblemBase.C:3858
#10 0x00007ffff4d94506 in FEProblemBase::execute (this=0x555555c53570, exec_type=...)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/problems/FEProblemBase.C:3771
#11 0x00007ffff45a0611 in FixedPointSolve::solveStep (this=0x555555cb9a30, 
    begin_norm=@0x5555572bd810: 0, end_norm=@0x5555572ba720: 0, transformed_dofs=...)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/executioners/FixedPointSolve.C:426
#12 0x00007ffff459f5ee in FixedPointSolve::solve (this=0x555555cb9a30)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/executioners/FixedPointSolve.C:273
#13 0x00007ffff3fdce02 in TimeStepper::step (this=0x555555dbede0)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/timesteppers/TimeStepper.C:163
#14 0x00007ffff45aeed2 in Transient::takeStep (this=0x555555cb91c0, input_dt=-1)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/executioners/Transient.C:446
#15 0x00007ffff45ae1f8 in Transient::execute (this=0x555555cb91c0)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/executioners/Transient.C:331
#16 0x00007ffff53cc3ab in MooseApp::executeExecutioner (this=0x55555569f5d0)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseApp.C:1076
#17 0x00007ffff53cf8c7 in MooseApp::run (this=0x55555569f5d0)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/moose/framework/src/base/MooseApp.C:1460
#18 0x000055555555d803 in main (argc=3, argv=0x7fffffffdec8)
    at /home/aiskhak/projects/fv_app/src/main.C:33

MooseVariableFE::getElementalValue (this=0x0
means the variable is null. It's probably because it's a FV variable and not FE.
I ll have a look.

What type is this extra variable you are adding? It's being recognized as a FE variable by that bit of code. If it's FV, then that's how the pointer s null.
There's clearly something wrong going on. Can you please try making it FV (fv = true or type=MooseVariableFVReal in variable declaration)

I am adding the following variable and coresponding kernel:
  [elvol_aux_var]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [] 

  [elvol_aux_ker]
    type = VolumeAux
    variable = elvol_aux_var
  []

The variable does not allow setting fv = True, which probably causes the problem

fv = True or type=MooseVariableFVReal
return:
*** ERROR ***
FV variables do not support setNodalValue

node.title: libMesh Update (2021.11.11)
node.bodyText:
A new libMesh made its way to the MOOSE master branch in November. For those using the conda packages, please perform
conda update --all

in your MOOSE conda environment. The appropriate moose-libmesh package version should be 2021.11.11. For those using the the libMesh submodule, please run in the moose/scripts directory
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

after updating your copy of MOOSE.
More details on the content of this update can be found in the November 2021 Newsletter.

UPDATE TO THE UPDATE BELOW
When conda (or mamba) update --all fails to correctly update libmesh, you can force an update to the right package with:
mamba update moose-libmesh=<latest-version-date>

The current version date, in early February 2022, is 2022.01.19. You will find the latest version date on the Discussions announcement.
If this fails, please follow the instructions below.
UPDATE
conda update --all has failed to correctly update libmesh on systems with higher versions of python that we currently allow. This will cause MOOSE build failures.
To confirm this issue is affecting you, please type conda list | grep libmesh and look at the version. If different from 2021.11.11 (or the current latest if you are looking at this comment in 2022), this is affecting your system.
The solution is to remove the moose conda environment and re-install it.
conda deactivate
conda env remove -n moose
conda install mamba -y
conda create --name moose -q -y
conda activate moose
mamba install moose-libmesh moose-tools
Also, your system might need a reboot after these commands :)

node.title: Custom Output with execute_on=CUSTOM
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Community
I wish to carry out comparisons for mesh convergence at different meshed but at a certain timestep for which I realise that one has to use execute_on = 'CUSTOM' in [Outputs] block but I am not sure how to use this functionality to get the desired output.
Many Thanks
Pushkar

Hello
Output to where?
CSV & exodus both output every timestep by default, so you wouldnt need to change this to get all the data available.
Guillaume
Thanks @GiudGiud  for elaborating on that and as of now I am outputting an exodus file but is it possible to get a output at certain timestep in VTK or any other visual format

Exodus can be visualized in paraview.
VTK can be output at every timestep as well.
Creating a CUSTOM execute_on to select a few timesteps is a little complicated, it's really better to just downselect from the every timestep output
thanks @GiudGiud for elaborating on that...

at the end of this page https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/interfaces/SetupInterface.html
are the instructions to create a CUSTOM execute on flag in your application btw

node.title: How to add compiler flags for additional includes or libraries?
node.bodyText:
Hello,
how do I add compiler flags to the Makefile of an application?
I tried
ADDITIONAL_CPPFLAGS = -I/path/to/include
at the beginning of the application's Makefile, but it doesn't have an effect.
Besides additional includes, I'll also need to link additional libraries.
(A related question: Is it possible to set something like a VERBOSE flag to the make command, so that every executed detailed step during the build process will be shown?)
Thanks
Friedrich

Hello
ADDITIONAL_CPPFLAGS := -I/path/to/include should be the way to do this.
Use make -n to get a dry run with all the commands that would be run.
Or make SHELL='sh -x' to run the commands and get output.
Guillaume

Thanks, this is very helpful, problem solved.
#19413 helped, too.
(I had a number of mistakes. Maybe this helps somebody else, who is not a Makefile expert, either:

I used ':=' instead of '=' (although '=' seems to work)
I wrote ADDITIONAL_CPPFLAGS = -I$(shell pkg-config --cflags ...) (Didn't show this in such detail above.) This was one '-I' too much, because the pkg-config output contains the -I already.

I also tried ADDITIONAL_INCLUDES instead of ADDITIONAL_CPPFLAGS. This seems to require '+=' instead of ':=', and it needs to appear before include $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/app.mk, whereas ADDITIONAL_CPPFLAGS :=... can go anywhere.
So this one worked for me as well:
...
ADDITIONAL_INCLUDES += $(shell pkg-config --cflags ...)
include $(FRAMEWORK_DIR)/app.mk
...

)

node.title: Node set id and Suface (Side set) id overlap in BCs on an Abaqus .inp mesh
node.bodyText:
hi everyone
I am new to moose. Recently, i tried to solve very simple linear elastic problems using moose tensor mechanics modules.
My mesh is built from an abaqus inp file. The boundary part commands are

Case 1
mesh contains:

the results are


Case2
mesh contains:

the results are


Case3
mesh contains

the results are


I guess Moose gives ids to Sets and Surface respectively according to their names, but the BCs are applied without distinguishing Sets boundaries (node sets) or Surface boundaries (side sets).
in Case1, it is,
Sets:  bottom = 0; left = 1; right = 2; top = 3
Surfaces: s_bottom = 0; s_left = 1; s_right = 2; s_top = 3
in Case2, it is:
Sets: all = 0; bottom = 1; left = 2; right = 3; top = 4
Surfaces: s_bottom = 0; s_left = 1; s_right = 2; s_top = 3
in Case3, it is:
Sets: all = 0; bottom = 1; left = 2; right = 3; top = 4
Surfaces: s_a0 = 0; s_a1 = 1; s_a2 = 2; s_a3 = 3; s_a4 = 4;  (they are all bottom side of the squre)
s_bottom = 5; s_left = 6; s_right = 7; s_top = 8
So everything goes well in Case1 because Sets and Surfaces have coincident ids，but in Case2, The boundary on "bottom" will be applied to both "bottom" and "s_left"  because they have same id  and the boundary on "s_top" is applied to both "right" and 's_top'.
Case3 works well again as expected.
The software information is
MOOSE Version:           git commit dbb9945 on 2021-12-20
LibMesh Version:         5f606f4dbd542262512cf701456d1ab7cbd65111
PETSc Version:           3.15.1
SLEPc Version:           3.15.1
This issue can be avoid by adjusting the mesh file. I just report this here. or you can ignore this if it's because I'm using moose in some inappropriate way.

Hello
Yes, MOOSE does this by default, for simplicity. All nodes from a given sideset are given the nodeset ID that is the same as the sideset ID (or equivalently, a nodeset with the same ID is created for every sideset), as explained here https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/mesh/MooseMesh.html
This is done at the end of the mesh generation. It's unfortunate that this ends up changing the result for your case since it makes the BC apply on more nodes than wanted. To avoid this, you can rename sidesets using a RenameBoundaryGenerator, in the [Mesh] block
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/RenameBoundaryGenerator.html
Guillaume

node.title: Estimate memory usage in advance
node.bodyText: Is there a rule-of-thumb for estimating the likely memory usage of a MOOSE problem, based on the DOF? I understand there are post processors that can report on memory usage, but it would be helpful to have an idea in advance in order to choose an appropriate number of nodes/cores to run a problem.

Hello
I would say at the very least > 3*(n_dofs_primary + n_dofs_aux) *sizeof(double)
But it'll depend on which numerical methods you are using to solve the system. A LU preconditioner would mean a full matrix to store, some preconditioners will include subsolves which will also require memory, a Krylov method would mean storing several basis vectors to represent the solution.
It'll depend if you use stateful properties or not, and for sure other things.
It should be fairly easy to determine this experimentally for your case by using uniform refinement and some of the memory postprocessors
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/MemoryUsage.html
@YaqiWang may have developed a measure for his application
Guillaume
Thanks, that's helpful. It hadn't occurred to me that the aux vars were taking up so much memory.

node.title: libMesh Update (2021.12.15) and December 2021 News
node.bodyText:
A new libMesh made its way to the MOOSE master branch in December. For those using the conda packages, please perform
conda update --all

in your MOOSE conda environment. The appropriate moose-libmesh package version should be 2021.12.15. For those using the the libMesh submodule, please run in the moose/scripts directory
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

after updating your copy of MOOSE.
More details on the content of this update can be found in the December 2021 Newsletter. If issues are experienced in updating from earlier versions of the moose-libmesh package, please see the comment in #19532 for information on how to fix your environment.

node.title: What is the formal order of accuracy of FV Navier Stokes kernels?
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I need to perform Richardson extrapolation, which requires knowledge of formal order of accuracy (in space and in time). However, I did not find it in the documentation.
Thanks!

Hello
In space:
If you use Rhie-Chow interpolation for velocity and 'average' for the advected quantity you can get second order accuracy.
But our most stable configuration right now is with first order upwing for the advected quantity, which will only give you first order accuracy. We are planning to add more second order schemes with limiters to avoid oscillations soon.
In time:
it ll depend on your time integration scheme. If you have not specified anything, you are using first order implicit Euler. There are second order schemes available as well, see: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Executioner/TimeIntegrator/index.html
Guillaume
